items.title: 🎬 Reducing Bias in Early Evaluation (6 mins.)
Evaluating and Converging Early Ideas
items.content:
Moving from ideation to evaluation

After a good brainstorming session or two, there comes a time when a decision is needed to move forward. To arrive at that decision, you need to evaluate the stockpile of ideas you’ve generated for viability, efficiency, and potential success. Moving from ideation (divergent thinking) into evaluation (convergent thinking) can sometimes feel like jumping head-first into cold water because it requires a significant switch in mindset.

But evaluation shouldn’t be a whiplash experience: In fact, you’ve probably already started evaluating towards a decision during the ideation process. For example, you might have identified some ideas that proved early on they just weren’t worth the time, or ideas that sparked some significant design pivots, or even some ideas that seemed like good fits and required greater effort to define further.

Convergent thinking

During ideation, as you narrowed down options to arrive at your final list of ideas, you were naturally employing convergent thinking. This thought process leverages evaluation and decision-making strategies to identify the most viable solution instead of divergent thinking’s aim to generate an endless amount of possible solutions. A term first coined in 1956 by psychologist J.P. Guilford, convergent thinking is used in conjunction with divergent thinking for creative problem-solving.

Convergent thinking involves evaluating all options to make decisions while also encouraging further exploration and innovation.

By evaluating every option with user research and the project’s needs in mind, you widen your ability to either build onto existing options or explore alternative approaches. You can use several methods to practice converging ideas, concepts, or problems in the design world.

  • Priority Matrix
  • Dot Voting
  • How-Now-Wow Matrix
  • SWOT Analysis
  • I Like, I Wish, What If
  • Rose, Bud, Thorn
  • Kano Model

Evaluating early ideas

When evaluating design ideas and solutions, remember to consider the viability, desirability, and feasibility of each.

Bill Moggridge -- designer, author, and co-founder of IDEO -- created a framework (see below) to visualize this unique overlap of considerations that designers often find themselves at the center of. You might have even seen a variation of this framework before, and it’s often referenced throughout the design industry to highlight how experience, design, and innovation often sit at the crossroads of people, technology, and business.

By assessing how well each potential solution addresses the needs of the project, team, and business, you’ll quickly identify the most viable ideas.

While convergent thinking aims to narrow down on the best solution, that doesn’t mean it has to be the final one. Moving from divergence to convergence is not a linear process.

In the Double Diamond model below, you’ll see that the two work best together when implemented as an iterative process. After you’ve spent some time evaluating and narrowing down your ideas, don’t be afraid to diverge again. This will allow you to identify better ideas and stronger solutions.

items.title: Prototyping Basics
items.content:
Prototype before you build

By taking the time to prototype our ideas, we avoid costly mistakes such as becoming too complex too early and sticking with a weak idea for too long.” — Tim Brown, CEO & President of IDEO

Prototyping falls into the second diamond of the Framework for Innovation. It is often followed by “testing” and preceded by “ideation.”

Prototyping is the process of creating an interactive version of a design concept (a prototype) to be used for testing, validating, or communicating to team members. By being able to test designs and ideas with users or stakeholders early, it can save time and resources and help the business understand where to take the product or offerings.

Prototypes can reflect different levels of polish.

  • Designers use low-fidelity prototypes to validate and test with users in the beginning stage of a project.
  • Mid-fidelity prototypes contain a bit more detail, and are used to communicate part of the solution to users. This stage occurs only when you have already tested and validated early assumptions.
  • Designers use high-fidelity prototypes to test visual considerations and usability, and to communicate final designs and interactions to a development team.

Regardless of how it’s created, the level of fidelity, or the amount of functionality presented, prototypes aim to capture the design or solution as simple as possible to allow for testing and communication.

Testing paper prototypes

Testing ideas on paper before working digitally provides an opportunity to collect user feedback at an early stage. Paper prototyping is cost effective, since ideas can be mocked up quickly on paper and problems can be identified early before investing time in higher-fidelity mockups or in development.

Paper prototypes can be tested with physical sheets of paper, or by importing sketches into prototyping software such as Figma or InVision.

Testing paper prototypes encourages users to offer more honest feedback, which they might be reluctant to give on a more polished design. However, paper prototype test subjects have to do more work to imagine what will happen on each screen. Because of this, UXPin offers tips on preparing for an effective paper prototyping session:

  • Designate one person other than the presenter as play the “human computer” or product simulator. The person playing the human-computer will simulate scrolling, swiping, navigating to different screens, and other functionality.
  • Rehearsing your test beforehand is essential so that the presenter and simulator are in sync. The presenter can work out a good cadence for the simulator to keep up with the presentation.
  • Follow standard usability test best practices. Standards like using a minimum of 5 users and recording the tests still apply.
  • If you’re giving users a paper prototype to inspect, ensure you provide guidance and annotations, so they know where to focus and what they’re supposed to test.

Eight Principles of Prototyping

Todd Zaki Warfel, author of Prototyping: A Practitioner's Guide, outlines eight principles for more effective prototypes.

  1. Understand the audience and intent.
  2. Plan a little—prototype the rest: spend some time on planning designs and solutions but really focusing time on testing and validating.
  3. Set expectations: what are the goals for the prototype?
  4. You can sketch: often prototypes can be done quickly on paper.
  5. It's a prototype—not the Mona Lisa.
  6. If you can't make it, fake it.
  7. Prototype only what you need.
  8. Reduce risk—prototype early and often.

items.title: Prototyping Tools
items.content:
Comparing prototyping software

In recent years, there's been a veritable explosion of prototyping tools in the design industry. While this has been a great boon to designers everywhere, and though there are annual reports of what is prevalent in the industry, it’s easy to feel overwhelmed by the options.

The challenge now is in knowing

  • When to use which tool
  • The benefits of each
  • Costs associated with each
  • Knowing which are worth learning or common in the industry.

Figma

Having started in 2016, Figma  is a relative newcomer, but it has become a leading design tool for vector based graphics editing and prototyping. It’s adaptability is mainly a result of it’s freemium offering and the fact it’s primarily web-based, (with additional offline features enabled by desktop applications for macOS and Windows).

Figma is free for individuals, while users can upgrade to unlimited projects and team functionality for $12/month. Figma offers browser-based live collaboration.

Adobe XD

Adobe XD  is a vector-based design and prototyping tool first released in 2017 by design industry giant Adobe Inc in response to Sketch’s rise in popularity with designers. You can quickly go from wireframes and mockups to static UI designs to interactive prototypes that simulate a user experience — using just XD for the whole design process.

Adobe XD offers free and paid plans, depending on an individual’s or team’s needs. As of this writing, paid plans start at $11.89/month.

Sketch

Released in 2010 as a vector based digital interface tool for designers, Sketch initially became the software of choice for digital designers. Originally focused on only interface design, it’s now adopted to user needs and offers prototyping and collaboration capabilities like it’s competitors. Extensions, plugins and integrations for Sketch, created by a large community, make it easy to expand on Sketch’s capabilities.

Sketch is Mac-only. A license costs a one-time $99 fee.

InVision

InVision is known for its ability to make prototypes quickly and easily to be shared with stakeholders who can also provide feedback within the same tool. InVision Studio, released in 2019, is it’s next generation offering more prototyping capabilities and design team collaboration features, allowing designers to build more advanced animation and micro-interactions

Comparison of prototyping tools

Cooper: Comparison of Prototyping Tools - Cooper created an interactive comparison tool that allows you to see which tools support what features. (11-minute read)

Pros and cons of popular prototyping tools - a great article to read to understand the strengths and weaknesses of each tool in paragraph form. (16-minute read)

Prototyping tools for click-throughs

The tools listed below are examples of tools available for simulating flow and basic navigation with a prototype.

  • InvisionApp - the most popular tool for prototyping simple wireframes and click-throughs, geared towards testing simple flow and/or visuals. (Web tool)
  • Marvel - simple web-based tool for prototyping flows, similar to Invision
  • Flinto - desktop-based prototyping tool with rich animation abilities.
  • Fluid UI - With Fluid UI, ideas can be prototyped in minutes and shared instantly. Sharing, feedback and collaboration are all built in.

Prototyping tools for complex interactions

The following are links to prototyping tools used in the industry for simulating more complex interactions. Feel free to click on the links below if you are interested in learning more about them.

  • Axure - ideal for prototyping websites or desktop experiences.
  • Proto.io - web-based tool that is great for prototyping high-fidelity mobile and tablet applications.
  • Framer - a tool built for interactions and great for testing high-fidelity prototypes.
  • Justinmind - complex web and mobile app prototyping and annotations (Mac & PC).
  • UXPin - ideal for prototyping web or desktop apps that require lightweight interactions, but has libraries to support mobile apps and wireframes as well.

items.title: Low Fidelity with Invision
items.content:
Benefits of low-fidelity prototypes

  1. More time to work on design, before the test.
  2. You can make quick iterations during the test.
  3. Low-fidelity prototypes put less pressure on users. Users may feel less obligated to "judge" your design, and be more likely to call out things that don't work, or any negative reactions.
  4. Designers feel less precious about low-fidelity prototypes. Designers are more likely to want to alter a sketch than a full-detailed design that they labored over.
  5. Stakeholders will realize changes need to be incorporated. When seeing a rough prototype, the expectation of the complete-ness of the project is better conveyed.

To create a basic, transitional prototype using Invision

  1. Sign in to your account.
  2. In the main navigation, click Projects, and then click the plus icon.
  3. Click Create New Prototype.
  4. Enter a prototype name and then select the device type.
  5. Click Next.

To upload screens manually

  1. Open your project and, at the top right, click the pink plus button.
  2. Click Upload Screens and select the files you want to add as screens.

You can also drag and drop any PNG, JPG, GIF, or PDF file over an open space in the screens tab.

To replace your screens

  1. Go to the screen you want to replace. 
  2. Drag and drop the updated image into the browser. The screen will be replaced. If you want to replace multiple screens, try doing so from the prototype home page. Click the upload screens and drag and drop all of the images to replace them.

Once replaced all hotspots, templates and comments will remain in place.

To connect/link screens

Once you’ve uploaded your screens to InVision, you can use Build mode to create hotspots, overlays, and other interactions.

To create hotspots

Hotspots link your prototype screens together. Depending on the project type (desktop, mobile, etc.), there are various behaviors.

  1. Open your prototype and navigate to the desired screen.
  2. At the bottom of the page, click the Build mode icon
  3. Click and drag around the desired hotspot area.
  4. In the hotspot pop-up modal, select the following options:
    • Link To: Set the destination screen the hotspot will link to.
    • Click/Hover: Determine whether clicking or hovering will trigger the hotspot. Hover is not available for mobile prototypes.
    • Maintain scroll position after click: Check this box if you don't want the scroll position to reset after clicking the hotspot.
    • Include hotspot in template: Check this box to duplicate a hotspot across multiple screens.
  5. Click Save.
  6. To resize an existing hotspot, click and drag one of the corners.

Source: Invision

items.title: Rapid Usability Testing
items.content:
Why usability test?

Usability testing involves observing target users as they engage with a product or prototype. Users are given a task to complete and are encouraged to think aloud, or verbalize their thoughts and decision-making processes as they move through the user interface.

Typically, the goals of a usability test include

  • Uncover problems in the design
  • Discover opportunities to improve the design
  • Learn about users and their behavior and preferences

Rapid usability testing lowers the risk of solving for the wrong problem or building the wrong solution. It involves gathering feedback using low-to-mid fidelity designs such as paper prototypes and wireframes. Discovering problems early means avoiding wasting money, time, and resources developing a flawed design.

Elements of usability testing

Participant

Usability test participants should fall into the product’s target audience. This might mean someone who is already using the product or service in everyday life, but it could also be someone with similar characteristics or needs of a target user group.

Participants shouldn’t tap silently through a wireframe prototype (or point silently at a paper prototype.) Instead, they should be encouraged to think out loud so observers can better understand participant behaviors, goals, thoughts, and motivations.

Task

During usability tests, participants should be provided with a realistic, actionable task scenario. Task scenarios are actions participants should be able to accomplish using a provided interface. These scenarios should reflect realistic goals that most visitors to your site or application may wish to reach.

  • Keep tasks realistic. Give users one task at a time, and allow the user freedom to apply their own decision making criteria. Find a pair of sneakers costing less than $100 allows the user more freedom than find a pair of red Nike high-tops.
  • Keep tasks actionable. Use action verbs like sign up, download, or purchase to encourage users to interact with the interface to solve for a specific need.
  • Avoid precise instructions. Don’t mention specific interface items or sections of your product, and avoid terms like click on or go to that might lead your user toward a specific outcome.

Facilitator

A facilitator is present to guide the participant through the usability test process. A facilitator needs to be able to provide instructions, answer participant questions, and ask clarifying questions in response to participant comments without influencing the participant’s feedback or behavior.

If a facilitator is not present, this is known as an unmoderated usability test. Unmoderated tests remove the possibility of the facilitator influencing the outcomes. On the other hand, unmoderated tests lack the possibility of asking follow-up questions or clarifying participant statements.
